title: WCAS POLI_SCI 390-0-24 Special Topics in Political Science
topic: Land Rights & Conflict in a Global Perspective

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Prof. Klaus, "Land Rights and Conflict in a Global Perspective" Spring 2016 co-list with INTL ST 390-0-23
For much of the world's population, land sustains livelihoods, shapes identities, and provides a source of
investment and security. Yet the centrality of land in everyday life also means that it can become a
source of contentious politics and violence. This class explores how struggles over access and rights to
land shape different forms of conflict and violence: between squatters and state officials, different
ethnic groups, or armed groups and the state.
The course explores questions of land and conflict in several parts. We begin by examining the question
of land meanings: what does land, property, and territory mean to different groups of people? How
does this help us understand why people organize or fight around issues of land? Second, the course
takes an historical and comparative view of the rules and institutions that shape people's rights and
access to land. The third part of the class explores theories that link land to conflict and violence. We
then apply these theories to explore a set of case studies of land-related conflict: from the recent armed
uprising in Oregon to civil war in Colombia. The last part of the class moves toward policy
considerations. How, for example, can a focus on land rights improve post-conflict resolution?
The course is interdisciplinary in its approach, drawing heavily on political science and political
geography. It should appeal to students interested in peace and conflict issues, environmental politics,
international development, and human rights.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Course Requirements
? Seminar Participation (30%)
? Critical Review Papers (2 x 10%)
? Final Research Paper (40%)
? Presentation of Research Paper (10%)
1. Participation
Students are expected to participate actively in each class and engage with the comments of their
classmates. Bi-Weekly questions: As part of the student's participation grade, I will ask students to send
two questions that they want to discuss before each seminar. Students should send these questions to
the class list no later than 8 am the morning that the class meets.
2. Critical Review Papers
Over the course of the semester, students will write two review papers based on the theme of a
particular week. In the first paper, the student will analyze the theories and concepts from a set of
readings, looking for assumptions or gaps in the literature (Concept paper). In the second paper,
students will examine and critique a methodological approach and/or research design from a set of
readings (Methods paper). Papers should be well argued and concise (avoiding summary of readings).
Critical Review papers should be 5-6 pages (double-spaced).
3. Research Paper
Students will work on developing their research papers over the course of the semester. Papers should
present a clear and well-motived research question that addresses themes or debates that we have
covered in the class. The paper should also present a clear set of hypotheses and should draw on
original data to support hypotheses. They should be 15-20 pages, due the final day of class.
4. Final Presentation of Research
Each student will give a 10-minute presentation based on their research paper during the last week of
class. Details TBA.
